Expectation1: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation1: A noise complaint is reported due to a late-night party disturbing neighbors
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: The station is set to lock its doors in ten minutes.
Story: The radio crackled just as I was about to leave for the polling station. “Unit 12, we’ve got a noise complaint on Maple Street. Residents say the party’s out of control.” I glanced at the clock—ten minutes until the polling station closed its doors. As a police officer, I knew I had to respond quickly; ignoring a call wasn’t an option. But as a voter, I’d waited weeks for this day, determined to have my say in the election. My supervisor always said, “Public order comes first,” but my civic duty tugged at me just as hard. I could already picture the disappointed faces of my neighbors if I let the party go on, and the regret I’d feel if I missed my chance to vote. My heart pounded as I weighed the badge on my chest against the ballot in my hand, torn between two promises I’d made to myself and my community.
